The Bible says in Jonathan Saul's son arose and went to David into the wood and strengthened his hand in God And he said unto him fear not For the hand of Saul my father shall not find thee and thou shalt be king over Israel and I shall be next unto thee and that also saw my father knoweth they too made a covenant before the Lord and David abode in the wood and Jonathan went to his house Again, if you will a lesson within a lesson really the thought of 1st Samuel 23 as we look throughout this passage of Scripture You find that it begins with the Philistines attacking the city of Keilah The Bible begins in verse number one and says then they told David saying behold the Philistines fight against Keilah And they robbed the threshing floors And so we find that David is made aware of the situation with the Philistines Attacking the city of Keilah and David inquires of the Lord He seeks the face of God he and his men go to Keilah and they provide deliverance from the Philistines I mean, that's a wonderful passage of Scripture the first five verses I mean you think about the victory that they experienced you think about the The joy that was in that city and amongst those people when they experienced the victory of the Lord and how God's guidance and leadership Gave them the direction that they needed for that particular time, but we find that the Bible tells us that they After they experienced victory that Saul was aware of what was taking place In fact, if you read in verse number seven You find that Saul was going to seize the opportunity if you will To go and get David and we know that he wanted them dead in verse number seven The Bible says and it was told Saul that David was come to Keilah and Saul said God hath delivered him into mine hand For he has shut in by entering into a town that hath gates and bars So what does Saul do he gathers the people of war together according to verse number eight and they were gonna go down to Keilah to Besiege David and his men. It's interesting that Saul was not the one he and his men they didn't come to help Keilah from the Philistines and We find that it was David and his men that went to the city to help deliver These inhabitants from the attack of the Philistines But now when Saul hears word that David is in this city And he looks at as being a grave mistake for he's shut in He's in a city a town that hath gates and bars And so Saul is going to seize his opportunity to finally get David We find that David inquires of the Lord he asked the Lord two simple questions as We look at the first really twelve verses of this passage of Scripture to really set the scene for what's going on And he asked two questions number one. He asked the Lord is Saul going to come See David had heard that Saul he'd heard about the plan that Saul had devised and that Saul was going to come and so David Inquires and he asked specifically of the Lord is Saul going to come you can read of that in verse number 11 and you find that God answers the specific request notice. It says will the men of Keilah Deliver me into his hand will Saul come down as my servant hath heard and the Bible tells us that the Lord God of Israel Gives an answer at the end of verse number 11. It says the Lord said he will Come down The second question that David asked and really it was posed first in verse number 11 But it's addressed second and the answer is given in verse number 12 And that question was this whether or not the men of Keilah would deliver him and his men into the hand of Saul the Bible says that God answered again at verse number 12 at the end. It says the Lord said they will Deliver thee up now. Can you imagine put yourself just for a moment in the shoes of David? he get the idea that I'm afraid right you understand but when we can can you sense when someone's afraid sure you can there are times and situations in which we can see on the countenance of an through it says that he sought him every day he saw him every day but God delivered him not into his hand what a blessing we find that Jonathan comes and he shows up and he says to David is he's there in his presence he says fear not for the hand of Saul my father shall not find thee then he tells him this and thou shalt be king over Israel see Jonathan understood the plan Jonathan understood what God was doing Saul no doubt was aware of it even as Jonathan mentions here at the latter part of verse number 17 that Saul also was aware of this plan remember that it was back before David ever was anointed to be king of Israel that God through Samuel had told Saul that God has rejected you from being king see Saul had been disobedient we find that there's occasion in which he did not wait as he was supposed to he did not obey in the manner in which he was to obey and we find that Samuel had to deliver that message to Saul that He was rejected by God. I do not believe that Samuel enjoyed delivering that message, for the Bible tells us that Samuel mourned for Saul. In fact, as you come to the first verse of 1 Samuel 16, the Bible says, "...And the Lord said unto Samuel, How long wilt thou mourn for Saul? Seeing I have rejected him from reigning over Israel. Fill thine horn with oil, and go, I will send thee to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have provided me a king among his sons." Who is that? It's David. And so Jonathan reveals to David, now I want you to understand, a man that's on the run, a man that's been hunted now for a number of chapters as recorded here in the book of 1 Samuel, he's delivered at the end of chapter 18. We find that there's the truth of what Saul's trying to do. He then makes it broadly known in chapter 19, he's delivered by his wife and protected by Samuel. And we find that as you go through chapters 19, 20, 21, 22, that David's on the run. And you find that he says to Jonathan at one particular occasion, there's but a step between me and death. And we think about understanding that's there in 1 Samuel 20 in v. 3, the latter part of the verse, but truly as the Lord liveth and as thy soul liveth, there's but a step between me and death. If you're in that situation, if you're considering the fact that you're being hunted, as you're considering the fact that there's but a step between you and death, the thought of being king of Israel is not really close on your mind. Right? What does Jonathan do? He reminds him of God's promises. He reminds him of God's plan. Jonathan comes to David. He comes to the place where he is. It says that he arose and he went to David into the wood. Strengthened his hand in God. He tells him to fear not. He then tells him that Saul's not going to find him. He reminds him of the plan and promise of God. He says, thou shalt be king over Israel. If God has ordained it that you're going to be king over Israel, and He has, and we know that you've been anointed to be king, you're not king yet, so you know that God is going to protect you. He's going to provide for you. Can you imagine the encouragement? See, there are times in our lives, thinking about the life of Jonathan, but also thinking about the life of David, there are times in our lives when we're in a situation, we're dealing with a level of circumstances and a difficulty in which we might think it's helpless. It's hopeless. We're not thinking properly. We're in a place where we're not thinking properly because of a circumstance, a situation that you're dealing with, and somebody's able to come alongside of you and remind you of some of what God's plan is, some of what God's promises are. It may not be that you have forgotten them entirely or completely, but it's just not fresh on your mind because you're dealing with all of these circumstances and all of these adverse situations that you're dealing with, and you say, I'm overwhelmed with these things. In fact, many of the psalms in which you read where David is crying out and saying, how long, O Lord? When David's crying out and saying that his heart is overwhelmed, many of those psalms are penned during this period of time of the book of 1 Samuel when he's on the run. And I can't help but think about the encouragement of Jonathan in this passage of Scripture. It's a lesson within the lesson. And think about the impact that it made on David's life in this very moment of time. The Bible says in v. 17, "...and I shall be next unto thee, and that also saw my father knoweth." The Bible tells us in v. 18, "...and they too made a covenant before the Lord, and David abode in the wood, and Jonathan went to his house." Jonathan couldn't stay where David was, but he risked whatever the cost would be, perhaps his life, to go to where David was to encourage him, to strengthen him. As I think about this passage of Scripture and I think about the truth that Jonathan strengthened David's hand, I wonder this evening, whose hand is it that God has for us to strengthen? Who is it that God may allow us to have some knowledge of a circumstance or situation that they're dealing with and God may use us to go and strengthen their hand? That we would take action. See, Jonathan was aware of the situation, but Jonathan took action. He did something about it. He was willing to go into the presence to risk maybe even his own life. Do you think that Saul would have been pleased to know that Jonathan was going to find where David was? No, this is a dangerous situation. Jonathan had already been in the presence of Saul once when Saul took a javelin and threw it at him. We find that Jonathan said, I need to go encourage my friend. I need to go and strengthen his hand in God. He was aware of what was going on. And this situation with David was again, a number of passages of Scripture, chapters that we read of this ongoing drama that David is facing and all of this difficulty that he's dealing with. And we find that he comes and they make this covenant and then David stays there in the wood and Jonathan returns to his house. As I think about this passage of Scripture and think about the role of Jonathan, I'm reminded of what the Bible tells us about Job. Go over to Job 4 if you will. Now, often we think about the book of Job. We think about all of the difficulty that Job encountered and certainly he had some great difficulty. You read there in Job 1 and you read of all the things that befell him and you read into chapter 2 and see how that it continues to just increase. And the Bible tells us that he had some friends at the end of chapter 2 that were going to go and they were going to come and they sought to bring comfort. And of course, we know that later in the book of Job, that Job will describe his friends as being miserable comforters. But I want you to consider what is said of Job in Job 4. In verse 3, it says, Behold, thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands. Thy words have upheld in him that was falling, and thou hast strengthened the feeble knees. Job was a man that was used of God to encourage many. To strengthen them. We see it in verses 3 and 4 here of Job 4. And of course, we find that it goes into the fact that now Job is in that position where he needs the encouragement. He's dealt with some tragedy, some difficulty, and now he needs the encouragement. And no doubt, there are times in our lives where we need encouragement, but this evening as we look at this passage of Scripture and we consider what's going on in the life of David, and we say, thank the Lord that Jonathan was sensitive to the need and Jonathan was willing to take action and go and strengthen the hand of David. And I just wonder this evening, I think about the New Testament. I think about many throughout the portions of Scripture that were used to be encouragers. Barnabas is probably one of the first examples that would come to our mind as one that was an encourager. No doubt, he encouraged Paul on a number of occasions. We find that as we would look throughout the Scriptures and we think about those that came and there were several that Paul would mention how they refreshed me. They oft refreshed me and how these individuals were used by the Lord to go and to seek him out, to seek to encourage him and to strengthen him. This evening, David was in a difficult situation. God delivered him just as Jonathan had given him the encouragement. God worked miraculously. If you read the end of 1 Samuel 23, you find that just as David and his men are completely surrounded by Saul and his men, that the Bible tells us that there came a messenger to Saul and said the Philistines have invaded the land and we find that Saul and his men have to retreat and go take care of that and God miraculously delivers David and his men. And what a blessing. But in the midst of the trial, Jonathan comes and strengthened his hand in God. This evening, is there someone that God might want you to encourage, to strengthen? Are we looking for that opportunity? No doubt there are times you say, pastor, I hear what you're saying, but I'm the one that needs encouragement. Sometimes it's easy for us to look at things that way. Amen? We're all dealing with difficulties and I'm not trying to discount those difficulties. I'm simply saying that God could use you to be an encouragement to someone else, to strengthen someone else. their truth from His Word, to be able to strengthen their faith to continue on. I can only imagine how David must have felt at the sight of Jonathan. I'm sure it was refreshing. It was encouraging. Just him coming. And then as they sat there and they talked and Jonathan shared these truths, reminded David, God has a plan for you, David. You're going to be the king. We find that David was strengthened by Jonathan. Oh, that God would use us in like fashion. Let's pray. Father, we love You this evening. We thank You for loving us. Lord, we thank You for the encouragement that You give us through Thy Word. We thank You for the examples that we're able to read of. We believe in this particular account here this evening of Jonathan being aware of the situation, but then taking action to go to where David was to speak to him, to encourage him, to strengthen him. God, this evening, I pray, You'd help us to be sensitive to the leadership of the Holy Spirit of God in our lives. Help us, God, to be used of Thee. Help us to encourage and strengthen the brethren. I pray that You would bless our time of prayer. We thank You for the privilege of prayer. We pray that You'd be honored and glorified through all that's said and done. For it's in Christ's name we pray, Amen.
